key_points: During the U.S. Capitol riot, police command structure collapsed, leaving officers to fend for themselves without leadership or plan.
Officers were inadequately warned about the scale of the threat from rioters, many of whom were better armed than the police.
Capitol Police Chief Steven Sund, who resigned following the riot, was with Vice President Pence and uncommunicative during the event.
Interim Chief Yogananda Pittman and Lt. Tarik Johnson provided limited instructions, complicating the response to the mob.
Despite previous online warnings of unrest, the Capitol Police rejected external support and had only planned for a free speech demonstration.
The riot resulted in five deaths, including a Capitol Police officer and another officer's subsequent suicide.
Federal agencies are reviewing the coordination and response failures that made the Capitol vulnerable.
There was confusion over whether the National Guard was requested, with differing accounts from police and congressional leaders.
Capitol Police lacked an adequate preparation and briefing process for the January 6 event, unlike for other major events.
Most rioters left without arrest due to the overwhelming number of rioters compared to police.
